title: Tawakkol Karman - Robert F. Kennedy Human Rights

quotes: Tawakkol Karman was born in 1979 in Taiz, Yemen’s third largest city, often described as a place of learning in a conservative country.
In 1990, she witnessed the unification of North and South Yemen, followed by a civil war in 1994 in which the North triumphed.
In 1990, she witnessed the unification of North and South Yemen, followed by a civil war in 1994 in which the North triumphed.
In 2005, she founded the organization Women Journalists Without Chains (WJWC), which advocates for freedoms and provides media skills to journalists.
From 2007 to 2010, Karman regularly led demonstrations and sit-ins in Tahrir Square, Sana’a.

In 2011, she redirected the protesters to support the Arab Spring and even brought Yemen’s revolution to New York, speaking directly with United Nations Secretary General Ban Ki-Moon and organizing rallies at the UN headquarters.
She was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2011 at age 32, one of the youngest people to ever receive it.

organizations.name: Sana’a University
quotes: Karman earned a master’s degree in political science from Sana’a University.

roles.title: journalist
quotes: A journalist by profession and human rights activist by nature, she responded to the political instability and human rights abuses in Yemen by mobilizing others and reporting on injustices.
